Additionally, Theorem 2 provides a new perspective on the DSE loss. While it has been traditionally viewed as an upper bound on the negative log-likelihood for the diffusion model, it can also be interpreted as an expected negative log-likelihood over factorial numbers of orderings for AO-ARM by Eq. 2.16. As discussed in [30], for different orders π𝜋\piitalic_π, qθ⁢(x0;π)subscript𝑞𝜃subscript𝑥0𝜋q_{\theta}(x_{0};\pi)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_π ) will be inconsistent in general. Despite this inconsistency, it can be viewed as an ensemble of multiple autoregressive models with different orders, potentially more robust than fixed-order models.

In [30, 31], it was proved that Eq. C.20 is mathematically equivalent to Eq. 2.16. Actually, Eq. C.20 is widely used as a training objective for any-order autoregressive models for efficient parallel optimization.

The table compares the average inference time (in seconds) for the SEDD small model using both Euler and Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping (T-τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ) sampling methods, and the RADD small model under a log-linear noise schedule with a caching strategy.
references: To assess inference efficiency, we measured the inference time on a single NVIDIA 4090 GPU with a batch size of 8, averaged over 1024 samples. The results are summarized in Table 3.

Across all sampling steps, the RADD model consistently required the shortest sampling time while maintaining similar perplexity levels to the SEDD model. Quantitatively, RADD achieved a speed-up of 2.5 to 3.5 times, as shown in Table 3. These findings align with the analysis of the E-NFEs in Fig. 2, validating the effectiveness of the RADD model and the caching strategy. They also demonstrate the practical implications of our Theorem 1.

A7.T4.4.caption: Table 4: Quality of unconditionally generated text evaluated by perplexity (↓↓\downarrow↓). For a fixed model, the best perplexity is bolded.
references: The results are presented in Table 4. Perplexity was calculated as the average over 1024 samples. For the random case, we calculated the average perplexity across different randomly generated π𝜋\piitalic_π. Generally, we found that directly sampling from the conditional distribution resulted in higher perplexity compared to Tweedie τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ-leaping or the Euler method with similar computational costs. Among the different decomposition orders, the forward order demonstrated the best performance.
